instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4668: What is 820-4668? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_OMOFF_L: What is SMC_OMOFF_L? This is a typo of SMC_ONOFF_L When you see SMC_OMOFF_L, assume they meant to type SMC_ONOFF_L.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hello

This iMac is here for the 2nd time. First it came as not turning on and it had a short on <CHIP>U3210</CHIP>, replaced and solved.

Now it came without any light on those LEDS.

I bought a new PSU and same behavior NO LIGHTS

I dissamble it and measure those resistors around the LED lights

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>

BEEPING TO GROUND - WHICH I GUESS IS HORT TO GROUND.

I then used my external psu to inject voltage at <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL>... Which was in short...

I saw a small smoke and turn off..

Then tried again it was in short for a few seconds and then it was gone... I guess something went bad in this process...

Anyhow now I do have NO SHORT at <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL>

but still short at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and NO LED lights... Anywhere to go?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
if you have <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL> present, it means the source is ok.

Now go to smc and check working condition.

Check <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
Power supply to the SMC
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> output signal

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> TPS LDO.

Enabling in the tps of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and S4

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Why to power on the board if you ALREADY detected a short on it???

Million times we said on the forum how to NOT inject voltage into PPBUS rail shorted to ground, but people still do it.
I bet you've created more damage on the board now.

Beep and short is not the same.
Usual multimeters beep until 050-075 readings, depending on models.
However, beep on mentioned rails is not a good sign.
But, did you think what means if the same reading was present on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and PPBUS rails???
Just shorted high-side MOSFET and you've injected 12V into <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>!!!

Post exact ohm value for the short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and anywhere else you think to have short.
And do NOT apply power again on <SIGNAL>12V_G3H</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Sorry for the mistake. I did everything that was in my mind. Since with 2 original PSU was no light and I decided to inject

Probably I burned the mosfet and did worse but lets fix it.

I went to measure right besides the LEDS (black probe on ground and red probe on the following with ohms selected on the multimeter)

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = <RESISTOR>R0304</RESISTOR> = PIN 1 = 14k = does not beep to ground
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = <RESISTOR>R0303</RESISTOR> = PIN 1 = 36ohms =  beep to ground 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = <RESISTOR>R0301</RESISTOR> = PIN 1 = 0.3ohms = beep to ground

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Need diode mode to ground reading at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> too; or where you've injected the voltage.

<CHIP>U8400</CHIP> is the common point for the 3V3 power rails mentioned above.
Remove it and check again for short.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Diode to ground (black probre on gnd and red probe on the line itself) @ <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL> = Open Line = Does not beep to ground

After removing <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>

PIN 13 = <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = BEEP TO GROUND 
PIN 1/6 = <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = BEEP TO GROUND

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Read about diode mode test (and more things):
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

When you have very low values, switch to ohm mode (usually under 010).
Multimeters beep until 050-075 readings (diode mode); that is not short.

Post ohm resistance to ground on the mentioned points.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
PIN 13 = <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 35.5ohms
PIN 1/6 = <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.5ohms

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
So, you have short to ground on L7610.
Lift one pin and check which side the short remains.

You can directly use voltage injection method to find the culprit...

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Removed L7610

I am going to inject voltage. Since its a 3.3 line do you suggest to inject 3V or start with 1V and increase til find?

Another question to make my logic process better next time. After the info I've got you how did you get to L7610?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> comes out from L7610.
Should be good to know if the short is before (to <TRANSISTOR>Q7610</TRANSISTOR>), or after the coil (pin 1).
However, injecting voltage directly also help.

NEVER inject the nominal voltage of the power rail.
Start with 1V and increase slowly, if needed.
Set first PSU amp limit to max.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Tks 

I found <CAPACITOR>C3280</CAPACITOR> in short. Now its gone. Assemble everything and got a light on the FIRST LED. However when trying to power up it doesnt start. As you said injecting 12V on the main live probably caused another trouble.

Should I start some rails measurement with the board assembled and powered through its own PSU? Until find something?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
12V from lab PSU is good enough for repair job.
Be sure to set amp limit to max.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_OMOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Some measurements


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3</SIGNAL> = 3.25
<SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL> = 11.98
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.28
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.38
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> =  0V

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.38 

If I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_OMOFF_L</SIGNAL> it goes to 0 and then back to 3.38

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
If detected, do the same for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Not sure what you mean by at the same time

But

Both are stable with 3.28V

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_OMOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>."
You should note the pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> [U]AT SAME TIME[/U] with <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drop pulse!!!

However, if these signals are steady high, you must have voltage on S3 and S0 power rails; check that.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
OK.


Remeasure the lines below

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V

Which S3 are you talking about?

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> = 3.28

Any idea where is the problem?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
You can check S4/3/0 enable signals at page 64.
For example, <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> is controlled by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, via <CHIP>U8500</CHIP>.
This power rail also requires power good signal from <SIGNAL>1V2_S3</SIGNAL>; controlled by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>1V8_S3</SIGNAL> power good required to enable <SIGNAL>1V2_S3</SIGNAL>).

I hope you've understood what I mean.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
S4
S3
S0

<RESISTOR>R8500</RESISTOR> 
PIN 1 =  3.28V
PIN 2 = 3.06V

<RESISTOR>R8520</RESISTOR>
PIN 1 =  3.28V
PIN 2 =  3.28V

<RESISTOR>R8504</RESISTOR> = 0V on both pins

<CHIP>U8500</CHIP>
PIN 5 = 0V

<RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> 
pin1 = 0v and beeps to ground

<RESISTOR>R8505</RESISTOR> = 0v on both pin

Could it be a bad <CHIP>U8500</CHIP>?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
BTW

Since <CHIP>U8500</CHIP>/<CHIP>U8600</CHIP> have input but do not have output I removed both of them.

Still <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> beeps to ground

HOWEVER I decided to measure resistance to ground to understand more about if its a short or not. 

Black probe on GND and red probe on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 36.6ohms

Would you mind give me an explanation if it's or not a short. For me usually when it beeps to ground it's a clear short to ground, if it was a CPU line which have low resistance to ground I guess it makes sense but a <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is a total short to ground in my humble logical mental process.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Do you get correct <SIGNAL>PP12V_S0_FET</SIGNAL>?
If not, change <TRANSISTOR>Q8450</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q8450</TRANSISTOR>
pin 4 = 0V
Replaced it and same behavior!

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U8450</CHIP> voltages.
Also check diode to ground at <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> power rail.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8450</CHIP>
Only PIN 1/5 have 11.98v

Diode to ground <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.880v
(Black probe on GND and RED on <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>)

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
You have 5 years on the forum and still check diode mode with black probe on ground :(.
Not relevant in this case, but is not expected to continue like that.

Seems that your problem comes from <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>.
You've mentioned low resistance to ground (not short) and didn't say anything about voltage.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
About 5 years and still some basic questions. For you to know I am the user of this forum, I do not have english as a first language. When you ask some questions to colleagues in this industry sounds like you are supposed to know everything. That's not how it works. Each person has its own time, Each person learns their own way (visually, trial and error, speaking) and to be honest there's a lot of SHALLOW explanation about theses problems. 

DIODE mode (RED ON GND and BLACK on <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>) = 0.481V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = (Diode Mode) = 0.020V and VOLTAGE = 0V

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: What would be a good way to find the culprit on the <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>? Injecting voltage? 1V?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
You can try voltage injection, but probably nothing will get hot.
May have luck if some chip enters thermal avalanche.
IR camera can help you a lot...

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Trying to inject voltage the amp on the LAB psu only goes to 0.0050 instead of full consumption 3A... Weird... I removed some components and still didn't find the culprit =(

Do not have thermal cam and I am not fan of them already have QianLi one.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Shold I put it higher to 3V?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
No more than 4V.
Is not easy to find something hot with finger touch.
There is very low power dissipated.

Why do you expect to get 3A???
Think a bit about Ohm law...

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hello

Bought a thermal cam and found <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> gettings hot. Removed it and now <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is back to business. Tried to power the power and both 1st and 2snd LED are now both 100% WORKING.

I didnt assemble the board or even left it into the PSU lab for few seconds just to notice this improvement

The question is since I do not have another <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and customer does NOT care about THUNDERBOLT ports.. Can I turn on this board without this IC and have it fully working except TBT?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Yes, it works without thunderbolt.
You can remove <CHIP>U3210</CHIP>/20, <CHIP>U3310</CHIP>/20 and <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> too.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
ok

But isnt 3210 and 3310 related to USB ports? USB ports customer will need it

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: As per schematic, these chips are in use with thunderbolt connectors only.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Thank you very much

Solved!

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
UPDATE

After assemble EVERYTHING (Tired of this iMac)

I plugged external USB mouse and keyboard on the first 2 ports and it did NOT work

Put on the 3rd and 4th PORTS and it works


UPDATE the system on the machine and now NO ports is working anymore... When I plug the mouse it has lights but it did not work. 

Really tired of this machine

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Didn't test USB ports before mounting the machine?

Check the small series coils from data lines.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
How to test USB ports before mounting the machine? Not sure how to do it on iMacs

What kind of check in coils would you recommend? Any specific component to give me the reference number?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"How to test USB ports before mounting the machine?"
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

"Any specific component to give me the reference number?"
There are many, L4602/03/04, etc.
Even <CHIP>U4610</CHIP> can give problems on its corresponding port.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I use the mouse to check USB activity however it has light on the optical sensor but NO movement.

Just a reminder after making it work I was able to use the keyboard and mouse (2 usb ports working another 2 were NOT working cause I tested)

Now I am only with the board on the LAB injecting 12V on the main line. 

Do I need to press power to measure USB components? 

Below are measurement without pressing the power button

<CHIP>U4610</CHIP>
PIN 1 = 0V
PIN 2 = 0V
PIN 3 = 0V
PIN 8 = 0V



L4602 = 0V ON ALL PINS
L4612 = 0V ON ALL PINS
L4702 = 0V ON ALL PINS

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
If CMOS battery is removed, board starts by itself, when power is applied.
Is better to use a bootable pendrive (with Link LED), to test USB activity.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
OK

Still I do not have USB activity on the mouse. Gave you some info about some USB components. Where should I go from here?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Would you replace <CHIP>U4610</CHIP> since it receives power on PIN 9 but does NOT output anytjhing?

PP3V42 = WORKING

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Update

<CHIP>U4610</CHIP>
PIN 9 = 3.40V
PIN 10 = 3.30

Should I replace it?

How may VOLTS should have on the coils?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U4610</CHIP> shouldn't block all USB ports; is used for J4600 only.
It can be removed, if in doubt; may be bypassed also.

Must check mentioned coils for continuity, not in voltage mode.
Do you get output voltage from <CHIP>U4600</CHIP>/700?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I did not remove <CHIP>U4610</CHIP>. Should I?

I checked the coil in continuity and none of them have short to ground? Is there any other continuity test you want me to make?

<CHIP>U4600</CHIP>
<CHIP>U4700</CHIP>

Both receive 5V and output 5V through pins 8/9. Is this enough?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I was talking about coils continuity; between I/O pins, not to ground.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Not sure what you mean for I/O pins

But I tested the following


L4602
PIN 3/4 DOES NOT HAVE CONTINUITY
PIN 1/2 CONTINUITY OK

L4612
PIN 3/4 =  DOES NOT HAVE CONTINUITY
PIN 1/2 =  CONTINUITY OK

L4702
PIN 3/4 =  CONTINUITY OK
PIN 1/2 =  CONTINUITY OK

L4712
PIN 3/4 = CONTINUITY OK
PIN 1/2 = DOES NOT HAVE CONTINUITY

L4603 / L4604 / L4613 / L4614 / L4703 / L4704 / L4714 / L4713
PIN 3/4 =  CONTINUITY OK
PIN 1/2 =  CONTINUITY OK

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Then fix the problem with lost connections; bypass them...

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Be sure no corrosion on that area.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Compare diode mode readings to ground with L4712.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I did and pretty much everything was the same value still not working. But if I plug the mice for example there is energy on it cause it makes the light work but no activity I guess some data related lines are not OK

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<DIODE>D4701</DIODE>/6 should be good, if you get similar readings with L4712.
Just in case, remove them and test again.
Only remains PCH as suspect; if J4700 looks good.

Be sure L4702 is really good...
